EFGLists.name: Sim Species with desc
EFGLists.EFGList: ?Lacks the tomato leaf odor characteristic of many solanaceous species. Most individuals have at least some leaves with small wart-like galls caused by mites.?

Items.name: Abundance
Items.Item: Common at 1000-1400 m, less abundant at higher and lower elevations.

Items.name: Comments
Items.Item: Because of its habitat and distinctive features, this species is hard to confuse with any other tree.

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: Small to medium-sized tree, reproductive at 2-10 m; bark beige, corky with deep virtical ridges and fissures; leaves alternate, often not paired, to 25 cm long, glabrous, elliptic, entire, often with small wart-like galls; flowers white in dense fasciles in leaf axils or at leafless nodes, bell-shaped, 1 cm long, with 5 recurved lobes, green-spotted inside, anthers cream, fragrant; fruit a 7 mm orange juicy berry with many small flat seeds.

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: Open areas such as roadsides, old pastures, and young secondary forest.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? small tree with corky, fissured, beige bark ? large simple leaves, rarely paired, often with wart-like galls ? 1 cm white bell-shaped flowers in sessile groups ? small orange berries

Items.name: Local distribution
Items.Item: Common in disturbed areas from 700 to 1500 m on the Pacific slope; rarely cultivated on Atlantic slope.

Items.name: Phenology
Items.Item: Flower: jan-feb, may-jun. Fruit: may-sep. Some individuals can be found in flower at any time.

Items.name: Pollinators
Items.Item: Small insects including bees, wasps, flies, butterflies, beetles, and ocasionally hummingbirds.

Items.name: Seed dispersers
Items.Item: The fruits are eaten by more than 40 species of birds.

Items.name: Species range
Items.Item: Mexico to Costa Rica; Ecuador and Peru.

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: Shrub, to 5 m tall; stems deeply grooved; leaves often paired at upper nodes, most with several tooth-like lobes, petioles long; flowers 7-9 mm long, yellow-green, shallowly lobed, anthers cream with outside face purple; fruit 7-10 mm, bright red, loosely enclosed by calyx.

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: Usually grows on recently disturbed soil in open areas, road sides, or large light gaps.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? leaves broad with few tooth-like lobes ? stems deeply grooved ? yellow-green flowers ? bright red-orange berries

EFGList.caption: Cestrum_?nuboso?#?-_blade_narrowly_elliptic.?
EFGList.serviceLink: Cestrum ?long petiole?#?- petioles more than 3 cm long.?

Items.name: Comments
Items.Item: This species is shade-tolerant and frequently occurs in forest understory.

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: Weak shrub, to 5 m, with few branches; leaves spiraled, solitary, glabrous, petiole to 2 cm, grooved, twig at base of petiole cup-like and often with a small bulb on each side, blade to 7 x 16 cm, broadly elliptic to weakly ovate, acute, base obtuse to rounded, midvein expressed above and below, lateral veins 7-9, minutely expressed above, especially at mid-leaf, but sunken in a shallow trough, tertiary veins faintly impressed above, raised beleow, texture slightly fleshy, no distinct odor; inflorescence 3-13 cm, axillary and terminal, often at leafless nodes; flowers with pedicels 0-1 mm, calyx 4 mm including 1 mm lobes, corolla yellow green, tube 18-19 mm, lobes 7-8 mm, pale green-white, glabrous inside, pubescent on margins outside; fruit to 13 mm long, white and spongey, apex dimpled; seed to 3.5 x 5 mm, dark brown, surface angled and minutely pebbled.

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: Cloud forest and wetter sites in Premontane wet forest, open understory and edge.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? leaf glabrous with short petiole ? tubular, cream-yellow flower ? white fruit

Items.name: Local distribution
Items.Item: Pacific slope from 1000 to 1650 m, Atlantic slope at 1300 to 1600 m.

Items.name: Phenology
Items.Item: Flower: feb-mar, jul. Fruit: mar-jul, nov.

EFGLists.name: Sim Species with desc
EFGLists.EFGList: Cestrum ?San Luis?#? is a smaller shrub with similarly shaped leaves
but it lacks the small stipule-like bracts of Cestrum fragile.?

Items.name: Comments
Items.Item: Quite distinct from other montane Cestrum spp. because of the distichous leafs and petiole bracts.

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: Treelet, 2-5 m; twigs round, green, sparsely pubescent; leaves solitary, distichous, each with a pair of ear-shaped bracts to 5 mm long that arise just above the petiole, petiole to 3 mm, deeply channeled above with distinct wing-like ridges, blades to 2.5 x 8 cm, lanceolate, acuminate, base slightly cordate to truncate, midvein keeled above, expressed below, lateral veins 8-9, flat to minutely raised above, expressed below, membranous, lamina weakly bullate, pubescence only of sparse minute hairs below, leaves are progressively smaller toward twig tip and becoming bract-like; inflorescence terminal, to 10 cm, green, delicate, but erect; flower 24 mm long, with calyx tubular, 4 mm, including 5 narrow linear 1 mm lobes, sparse pubescent, corolla tube 18 mm, 1 mm diameter at base expanding to 2 mm at level of anthers, yellow green, glabrous, lobes 5 mm, glabrous outside in the central exposed part, the infolded sides with short pubescence, inside glabrous, cream yellow, stamens free for 3 mm, a small tooth at point of insertion, a few minute glandular hairs on the tooth and on the filament track below, middle of tube with sparse long hairs, style 17 mm, minute glandular hairs in distal quarter, pale green, stigma green; fruit 10-15mm, white.

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: Light gaps, stream margins, and along roads in the forest.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? treelet with solitary, distichous, glabrous leaves ? a pair of 5 mm stipule-like bracts at base of each petiole ? cream flowers with narrow tubes ? white teardrop-shaped berries

Items.name: Local distribution
Items.Item: Pacific slope at 1500-1600 m (leeward cloud forest).

Items.name: Phenology
Items.Item: Flower: jan-feb, may-jun, oct. Fruit: oct-nov.

EFGLists.name: Sim Species with desc
EFGLists.EFGList: ?Very similar to three other Cestrum spp. at Monteverde. These as yet unidentified species have cream-white

Items.name: Comments
Items.Item: This may actually be an undescribed species related to Cestrum irazuense.

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: Treelet, reproductive at 1.5-3 m; twigs smooth, pale brown with few lenticels, glabrous, petiole insertion with a pair of distinct bulb-shaped appendages; leaves solitary, petioles to 2 cm, U-shaped, with a shallow channel, blades to 4.5 x 13 cm, elliptic, acute, base obtuse, margin unevenly undulate, midvein strongly keeled above, expressed below, lateral veins 5-6, basal pair strongly ascending, middle two pairs minutely keeled above, those at base and apex flat, blade glabrous, soft and somewhat fleshy; inflorescence axillary to distal leaves and terminal, 1-3 cm, glabrous, green, appearing racemose or with very short lateral branches, bearing 3-10 flowers, the leaves diminishing in size to bracts near inflorescence apex; flowers with pedicel 1 mm, distinct and uniform, calyx 3.5-4 mm, including 5 short triangular lobes about 0.8 mm, glabrous or with sparse scale-like hairs at apex of lobes inside, corolla tube 18-20 mm, pale purple white, glabrous, lobes 5, 4-4.5 mm, slightly recurved at anthesis, lavender purple, often darker in center of each lobe, outside glabrous in center, margins pappilose, not infolded, glabrous inside, stamens 5, filaments free for 4.5-5.5 mm, a small tooth less than 1 mm above insertion, the tooth pubescent, filament tracks sparse pubescent from insertion to corolla base, ovary globose, apex feintly 4-lobed, pale green, translucent yellow nectar disk at base, style 17-19 mm, white, short pubescent in distal 1/5, mild sweet fragrance; fruit a small spongy, white berry.

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: Open understory, light gaps, forest edge, and sunny trails in forest.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? treelet with glabrous, narrow elliptic leaves ? bulbous twig expansions next to petiole ? tubuler, lavender-blue flowers ? small white berries

Items.name: Local distribution
Items.Item: High peaks and ridges from 1550 to 1800 m (Cerro Amigos, Cerro Chomogo, Cerro Sin Nombre, La Ventana, Brillante Trail, Reserva Santa Elena).

Items.name: Phenology
Items.Item: Flower: jan, mar-may, jul, oct. Fruit: sep, feb.

EFGLists.name: Sim Species with desc
EFGLists.EFGList: Cestrum irazuense#?- leaves with fewer veins
twig bulged out at petiole insertion
twig bulged out at petiole insertion
Cestrum megalophyllum#?- broad leaves oblanceolate with purplish petioles.?

Items.name: Comments
Items.Item: Flowering occurs in short synchronized bursts lasting just a week or two.

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: Treelet, 3-5 m; stem gray brown, without lenticels; leaves spiraled, solitary, petiole to 12-15 mm, shallowly grooved, blade to 5 x 12 cm, glabrous, lanceolate to elliptic, tip gradually narrowed, acute, base rounded, slightly unequal, midvein keeled above, lateral veins 8-12, flat to impressed above, weakly expressed below, leathery to fleshy; inflorescence axillary, 5-25 mm, often branching near base, peduncle 2-10 mm, green to maroon; flowers with pedicel 0-1 mm, bracts 3 mm, linear, calyx tube 2.5 mm, 5-lobed, lobes short triangular, glabrous outside, pubescent inside and along distal margins, corolla with tube 13-18 mm, pink-white to maroon, glabrous, lobes 5 (4-6), 4-5 mm long, densely puberulent outside, glabrous inside, pink shaded with pink maroon in center, stamen filaments free, 2-2.5 mm, not toothed, glabrous at insertion and at base of tube, ovary and nectar disk pale green, style 16 mm, puberulent in distal 1/4, stigma capitate (lozenge shaped), strong odor at night; fruit 5-9 mm wide x 7-12 mm long, elliptic to obovate, smooth and shiny, green to dark red to maroon to purple-black when mature, calyx with lobes splitting and recurving, pedicel 3-5 mm, 1-7 seeds; seed dark brown, angular .

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: Common in light gaps, forest edge and partly shaded pastures.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? leaf lanceolate, rounded base, glabrous, sprialed ? cream-green to purplish tubular flowers ? shiny purple-black fruit with angular seeds

Items.name: Local distribution
Items.Item: Pacific slope at 1200 to 1500 m, premontane wet forest and generally not in cloud forest.

EFGLists.name: Sim Species with desc
EFGLists.EFGList: Cestrum ?lance leaf?#?- leaves are narrowly lanceolate and thicker.?

Items.name: Comments
Items.Item: Usually grows in disturbed areas with partial shade to abundant light; rarely seen in forest understory.

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: Treelet, 2-7 m; twigs round, glabrous, brown-green until quite large, petiole insertion cup-like with a globose bulge on each side, the bulge often purple; leaves spiraled, solitary, glabrous, petiole to 5 cm, grooved above by distinct dorso-lateral ridges, blade to 11 x 20 cm, elliptic, acute, base obtuse, margin often minutely ragged-edged, midvein keeled above, lateral veins 9-12, minutely keeled above, expressed below, loop-connected, fleshy to leathery, no strong odor; inflorescence axillary and terminal, 1-17 cm, mostly solitary, but occasionally branched from near base, paniculate, erect, glabrous to scruffy brown pubescent, bearing about 10-30 flowers; flower with pedicel 0-2 mm, calyx 4-5 mm, lobes 1.3 mm, sharp triangular, glabrous except for minutely puberulent at tips of lobes, corolla tube 1.5 cm, glabrous, yellow green, inside dense short pubescent especially along filament tracks, 5 lobes, 4 mm, outside yellow-green, glabrous in center, margins pappilose and deeply infolded, inside cream, glabrous, stamens 5, filaments free for 3-4.5 mm, anthers, at height of bulge in corolla tube, a prominent tooth 1 mm above filament insertion, bearing long crooked white hairs, ovary globose, weakly lobed apically, pale green, glabrous, style 14-15 mm, glabrous, minutely puberulent in distal 1/4, stigma lozenge-shaped, nectar disk translucent yellow; fruit to 12 mm wide x 10 mm long, apex dimpled, white, spongey, calyx light green, cylindical, 5-lobed, the lobes appressed, regular or often split in the sinuses, glabrous except for pubescence at the tips of the lobes; seeds 2-3 x 4 mm long, 1-12/fruit, olive green with a brown center on outer facet, crowded into a tight hemisphere in each half of fruit.

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: Upper premontane and lower montane zones, clearings, roadside, forest edge, stream margins.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? large glabrous leaves with petioles more than 3 cm long ? tubular yellow-green flowers in dense inflorescences ? white teardrop-shaped fruit

Items.name: Local distribution
Items.Item: Pacific slope at 1450-1550 m (rarely at lower elevations in moist canyons); Atlantic slope at 1200-1500 m.

Items.name: Phenology
Items.Item: Flower: feb-may, jul. Fruit: apr-jul, sep.

EFGLists.name: Sim Species with desc
EFGLists.EFGList: ?Of about 10 species of Cestrum in the region
this is the only one with oblanceolate leaves. Leaf blades of the others are ovate

Items.name: Comments
Items.Item: The large oblanceolate leaves are distinctive. Flowering occurs in short bouts that are usually synchronous among many individuals in the population. The nocturnal flowers are fragrant at night, but the scent is weak. The petioles are often purple in life and typically dry black.

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: Treelet, 3-6 m; twigs with cup-shaped petiole insertion, but bulbous lateral appendages lacking; leaves to 8 x 17 cm, petiole to 15 mm, blade glabrous, oblanceolate to less often elliptic, tip blunt to abruptly acute, midvein expressed above and below, lateral veins 9-12, finely keeled above, but sunken in troughs, faintly bullate, thick and leathery, semi-succulent, odor weak; inflorescences 1-3 per axil, 1-7 mm long, minutely pubescent; flower with calyx tubular, 4 mm, maroon, lobes 1 mm, corolla tube 13-14 mm, pink-white, glabrous, lobes 5-6, 3.5-4 mm long, cream shaded with maroon, puberulent outside, glabrous inside, white hair tuft at base of filaments, tuft at base of corolla, nectar disk appressed to base orange green, inconspicuous, style 12-13 mm, minutely puberulent apically, stigma capitate, green, mild sweet odor at night; fruit 5 x 10 mm or larger, purple-black, juice staining purple, often 1-seeded.

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: Light gaps and stream margins in primary forest, old pastures, and secondary forest.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? treelet to 6 m tall ? large glabrous leaves, widest beyond middle ? tubular lavender-white flowers ? oblong purple-black berries

Items.name: Local distribution
Items.Item: Both slopes up to 1550 m; down to the lowlands on the Atlantic side; down to about 900 m on the Pacific side in wetter microhabitats.

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: A treelet, mature at 2-5 m; leaves glabrous, 6-11 cm long x 4-6 cm wide, lanceolate, apex acute to acuminate, base acute, often weakly bullate; flowers yellow-green, tube 15-20 mm long; fruit white and juicy, 6-11 mm long.

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: Large light gaps, river margins, and forest edge.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? treelet to 5 m tall ? leaves glabrous, lanceolate ? flowers 14-19 mm, yellow-green ? fruit white

Items.name: Phenology
Items.Item: Flower: any time of year. Fruit: sep-jan.

EFGLists.name: Sim Species with desc
EFGLists.EFGList: Cestrum ?lance leaf?#?- twig without swellings next to petiole

Items.name: Comments
Items.Item: This species is vegetatively quite similar to Cestrum irazuense and C. ?lance leaf?.

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: Treelet, to 4 m; twig with a pair of bulb-like expansions next to petiole; leaves alternate, solitary, glabrous, narrowly lanceolate, apex acuminate, base acute to obtuse, lateral veins 8-12, flat above; flower white with pink flush, 2 cm; fruit white.

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: Open understory and light gaps in cloud forest.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? bulb-like swellings next to petioles ? leaf lanceolate with narrowed base and lateral veins flat above ? flowers cream flushed with pink ? fruit white

Items.name: Comments
Items.Item: Notable for its extremely pungent rank odor. Leaves usually bent upward on the margins forming a V in cross-section.

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: Tree, reproductive at 4-10 m tall, reaching 22 cm dbh, leaves to 5 x 13 cm, alternate and solitary, membranous, lanceolate, lateral veins sunken above creating a bullate appearance, strong rank odor even in undamaged leaves, tubular cream-green flowers 15-18 mm, on short axillary and terminal inflorescences, fruit 6-10 mm, a shiny purple-black elliptic berry.

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: Roadside, forest edge, rarely in forest light gaps.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? leaves glabrous, lanceolate, with strong rank odor ? lateral veins sunken above creating a pleated appearance ? tubular cream-green flowers ? shiny purple-black elliptic berries

EFGLists.name: Sim Species with desc
EFGLists.EFGList: Cestrum fragile#?- most nodes with a pair of very small bract-like leaves
Cestrum racemosum#?- leaves larger with sunken veins and strong rank odor.?

Items.name: Comments
Items.Item: Characteristic of the understory in seasonal forest of the Pacific slope below Monteverde. This species has been identified by various taxonomists as C. alternifolium, C. fragile, C. glanduliferum, and C. nocturnum, but does not seem to match any of them in the Flora of Nicaragua treatment.

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: Shrub to 1.5 m; twigs round, slender, pubescent when young, forming a cup around petiole insertion, but lateral bulbs absent; leaves distichous, solitary, glabrous, petiole to 3 cm, blade to 3 x 11 cm, lanceolate, acuminate, base rounded to abruptly cuneate, decurrent on petiole, midvein keeled above, lateral veins 7-12, weakly raised above and below, texture membranous, no distinct odor; inflorescences axillary, 1-2 cm, with about 6-9 flowers, each flower with a leaf-like elliptic bract about 3 x 10 mm; flower glabrous, sessile, cream to cream-yellow, calyx 3 mm, with lobes 0.6 mm, glabrous outside, lobes pubescent inside, corolla tube 2 cm, lobes 5-6 mm, pubescent outside along margins, glabrous inside, filaments free for 4-5 mm, tooth weak to prominent with short hairs, style 20 mm, sparse pubescent apically; fruit to 8 x 11 mm, white, spongy, not juicy, with up to 6 seeds.

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: Understory and light gaps in moist forest.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? understory shrub les than 2 m tall ? seasonal forest habitat ? white tubular flowers ? white fruit

Items.name: Local distribution
Items.Item: Seasonally dry forests on Pacific slope at 50-1000 m.

EFGLists.name: Sim Species with desc
EFGLists.EFGList: Cestrum megalophyllum#Cestrum racemosum#? both are glabrous.?

Items.name: Comments
Items.Item: This species is mostly seen as a shrub or treelet in early successional areas, but it can grow into a medium-sized tree with a dbh of 30 cm. The other Cestrum species in the region are glabrous. Because they usually do not have paired leaves, Cestrums are not immediately identifiable as Solanaceae. Some have a strong rank solanaceous odor, but others have none. All species have tubular nocturnal flowers, mostly pollinated by Lepidoptera. Many species of Solanaceae in the genera Cestrum and Solanum are called Zorillo because of their disagreeable odor. Those with red or orange fruits are often called Tomatillo (= little tomato).

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: Shrub or tree, 3-15 m; twigs with white lenticels, dense pubescence of beige feather-like hairs; leaves to 7 x 12 cm, petiole 1-1.5 cm, round, pubescent, blade broadly lanceolate, tip acute, base obtuse, margin entire, midvein raised above, lateral veins 7-9, impressed above, blade with stellate and plumose hairs sparse and short above, dense and long below, soft to the touch, strong acrid odor; inflorescences terminal, axillary, and at lower leafless nodes, 5-25 mm long, often developing on short new axillary twiglets with or without leaves; flowers with 1-5 mm pedicel, calyx 5 mm, 5 lobes 0.8-1 mm, pubescent, corolla 14 mm with 10 mm tube, glabrous, 5-6 lobes, 4 mm, infolded along margins, stamens yellow-green; fruit to 8 x 11 mm, shiny purple black; seeds to 2.5 x 4.5 mm, black with a pebbled surface, 1-4/fruit.

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: Open successional areas such as abandoned pastures and roadsides.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? treelet without spines ? leaf underside with dense carpet of stellate hairs ? tubular pale green flowers, 15 mm long, nocturnal ? oblong purple-black berries

EFGLists.name: Sim Species with desc
EFGLists.EFGList: Cuatresia riapria#?- minor leaf larger and elongate
Witheringia cuneata#?- midvein often pubescent below

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: Shrub or small tree to 6 m, 4 cm dbh; twigs often with two ridges on dorsal side, nodes swollen; leaves distichous, paired, glabrous, on flowering twigs major leaf to 10 x 22 cm, blade elliptic, acuminate, base asymmetric, but equal, lateral veins 9-11, weakly expressed above, minor leaf to 1.5 cm, almost round; flowers in sessile fascicles with up to 10 flowers, arising between and distal to petioles, flowers 4-parted, glabrous, with calyx 3.5-4 mm, without lobes, corolla pale green, 12-16 mm long, lobes 8-10 mm long, 3 mm wide, style exserted 2 mm, anthers ivory; fruit a 1 cm, yellow-green berry partly enclosed by calyx.

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: Light gaps in wet gullies and stream margins.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? major and minor leaves differ greatly in size ? axillary groups of several to 10 pale green flowers ? green fruit partly enclosed by calyx

Items.name: Local distribution
Items.Item: Cloud forest and wet forest on Pacific slope at 1100 to 1500m.

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: Treelet, mature at 2-6 m. Leaves distichous, paired, glabrous; flowers sessile in leaf axils, usually solitary, corolla yellow-green, 2 cm long, fruit to 12 mm long, a green berry mostly enclosed by the calyx.

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: Common in understory and edges of wetter forests on both slopes, in stream canyons in drier areas.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? treelet with paired, glabrous leaves ? 2 cm solitary yellow flowers ? yellow-green berries partly enclosed by calyx

Items.name: Local distribution
Items.Item: Cloud forest on both slopes, less abundant in wet forest on Pacific slope.

Items.name: Phenology
Items.Item: Most of year, with peak in wet season.

EFGLists.name: Sim Species with desc
EFGLists.EFGList: Cyphomandra betacea#?- the cultivated tree tomato.?

Items.name: Comments
Items.Item: This species was recently lumped with the genus Solanum as S. circinatum Bohs. Stem leaves tend be to much larger than crown leaves and are often deeply lobed. The distinctive, pendant inflorescences arise at twig divergences, (most Solanum spp. have erect inflorescences). These small trees grow in light gaps and old clearings. The fruit are eaten in Panama.

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: Treelet to 7 m; sympodial growth pattern, leaves alternate, glabrous, ovate to heart-shaped, stem leaves often larger and deeply lobed, strong rank odor; long-lasting pendant inflorescences with 2 cm purple-blue flowers; fruit elliptic to 3 cm, purple with fleshy rind and many seeds.

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: Light gaps in primary forest, forest edge, secondary forest.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? treelet with lobed stem leaves ? pendant inflorescences from branch forks ? purple-blue flowers ? fleshy elliptic fruits

Items.name: Local distribution
Items.Item: Atlantic slope from lowlands to about 1200 m; less common on the Pacific slope mostly to the north of Monteverde (Los Llanos to Las Nubes).

Items.name: Phenology
Items.Item: Most of the year, but especially wet season.

EFGLists.name: Sim Species with desc
EFGLists.EFGList: flowers yellow-green with dark green spots
lobes of fruiting calyx with purple lines below.?

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: Herb to 1.5 m; leaves paired, nearly glabrous, often with weak, tooth-like marginal lobes; flowers with corolla green-white, lobes nearly fused, a few green markings inside at base, calyx lobes fused; fruit a purple-black berry to 15 mm, calyx persistent and horizontal, not appressed to berry.

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: Overgrown pastures, coffee fields, roadsides, partly sunny stream margins.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? erect herb to 1.5 m ? upper leaves paired with weak marginal lobes ? flower white with green spots ? fruit calyx persistent with lobes fused, without purple lines below

Items.name: Local distribution
Items.Item: Pacific slope from lowlands to 1400 m.

EFGLists.name: Sim Species with desc
EFGLists.EFGList: Schultesianthus megalandrus#? has a similar growth habit
but is glabrous and occurs in wetter habitats. Hillia and Cosmibuena species Rubiaceae are similar hemi-epiphytes with opposite leaves.?

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: Appearing as a hemi-epiphyte or liana climbing tree trunks, usually growing near streams; leaves simple alternate and bunched at twig tips, entire, obovate, with minute pubescence of scruffy stellate hairs; flowers minutely pubescent with stellate hairs, calyx 3 cm, dull orange, corolla 6 cm, brighter orange than clayx, slightly down-turned and widened below the apex, 5 small apical lobes, stamens and stigma included in tube; fruit a dull yellow berry.

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: In tropical moist forest, usually growing in trees in the flood zone of streams, but also occurs in wet forest habitats.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? growth form of hemi-epiphyte or tree trunk climber ? obovate leaves with tiny scruffy stellate hairs ? orange flowers and calyx ? globose juicy yellow fruit

Items.name: Local distribution
Items.Item: Pacific slope from lowlands to about 800 m, (Río Guacimal at Finca San Luis and Guacimal, Quebrada La Guaria).

Items.name: Phenology
Items.Item: Flower: dec-may + (extended flowering pattern). Fruit: may-jun.

EFGLists.name: Sim Species with desc
EFGLists.EFGList: shade tolerant shrub of the same general habitat with a similar leaf conformation
the flowers and fruits have much shorter pedicels with only 5 calyx lobes
and the fruits are yellow-green when mature.?

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: Shrub, mature at 0.5-1.5 m; twigs somewhat zig-zag, with dense long simple hairs, nodes swollen; leaves distichous, paired, with sparse, appressed, long white hairs above and below, petiole 5-8 mm, blade to 4 x 11 cm, minor leaf to 2 x 4 cm, narrowly elliptic, very asymmetric, apex acuminate, base acute and unequal, bullate, midvein and lateral veins expressed above, lateral veins 9-12, loop-connected; inflorescence less than 1 mm with flowers almost sessile, arising between leaf pairs; flowers with pedicel to 30 mm, calyx with long simple hairs, 10 linear appendages, corolla white; fruit a shiny red berry to 9 mm wide x 7 mm long; seeds dark orange-brown, 1 x 1.3 mm, subtriangular and irregularly compressed, surface minutely textured.

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: Shaded trails and stream margins in primary and secondary forest. More shade tolerant than most species of the family.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? 0.5-1 m shrub in shade ? paired hairy leaves in a plane ? 10 thread-like calyx lobes ? round, red berries

Items.name: Local distribution
Items.Item: Pacific slope at 1300-1600 m (premontane wet forest to leeward cloud forest).

EFGLists.name: Sim Species with desc
EFGLists.EFGList: Lycianthes synanthera#? also has glabrous leaves and blue flowers

Items.name: Comments
Items.Item: The velvety green leaves are distinctive and attractive when fresh.

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: Treelet to 5 m; leaves paired, petioles to 1.5 cm, blades to 6 x 15 cm on reproductive twigs, larger on stems, elliptic to oblanceolate, entire, acuminate, base acute and extending along petiole, midvein expressed above, lateral veins finely expressed above, upperside with a velvety, glossy sheen, minute hairs on veins below; flowers sessile in leaf and twig axils, pedicels to 2.5 cm, calyx with 10 ribs without appendages or teeth, corolla purple inside, pale green outside, 15 mm long, 28 mm across, anthers dull yellow, style exserted 4-5 mm; fruit 12-16 mm long, subglobose, orange when mature, green immature, only 1-2 per axil; seed 1.5-2 mm long, hard and flat, beige-cream.

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: Usually grows in the repeatedly disturbed, rocky flood zone bordering streams and rivers in bright light, also wet rocky landslides.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? 1.5-5 m treelet along streams ? paired glabrous leaves with a velvelty sheen ? purple waxy flowers with a10-ribbed calyx

Items.name: Local distribution
Items.Item: Atlantic slope from lowlands to about 1000 m; Pacific slope at about 700-1100 m (Finca Ecologica, San Luis), usually in the flood zone of streams.

EFGLists.name: Sim Species with desc
EFGLists.EFGList: Lycianthes multiflora#? is a vegetatively very similar climber with larger leaves and white flowers that grows at slightly lower elevations.?

Items.name: Comments
Items.Item: No ithomiine butterflies are known to use this species at Monteverde.

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: Liana, mature at 2-8 m; stems woody, pubescent with stalked stellate hairs; leaves often paired, densely pubescent, petioles to 2 cm, blades to 5 x 8 cm, stiff erect hairs above, stalked stellate hairs below, ovate, apex acute, base rounded, 4-5 lateral veins, expressed above and below, minor leaf 70% as long as major leaf; flowers almost sessile, arising between leaf pairs, pubescent, pedicel 2 cm, calyx 3-4 mm long, plus 10 linear lobes, 2-3 mm long, corolla 20 mm long, lavender, lobes webbed to apex, anthers 7 mm, slender, beige with purple shading, style 9 mm, style and ovary glabrous; fruit a globose berry to 15 mm, bright red-orange when mature.

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: Sunny trails and road sides, especially in sites exposed to the northeast trade winds.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? liana of high cloud forest ? densely hairy paired leaves ? blue flowers with fused lobes ? round red-orange berries

Items.name: Local distribution
Items.Item: High peaks and ridges in cloud forest (Ventana, TV towers, Chomogo Trail).

Items.name: Phenology
Items.Item: Flower: mar-may, nov. Fruit: jun-jul, sep.

EFGLists.name: Herbivores
EFGLists.EFGList: Ithomia patilla#Napeogenes tolosa#Oleria paula#Oleria vicina#Pteronymia artena#

EFGLists.name: Sim Species with desc
EFGLists.EFGList: Lycianthes furcastistellata#? is a very similar liana of high cloud forest ridges with small
ovate leaves and blue flowers. The other local Lycianthes spp. are shrubs

Items.name: Comments
Items.Item: A common liana on forest edges on both slopes.

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: A woody liana, reproductive at 3 to 10 m; stems to 1.5 cm, without spines; leaves to 9 x 14 cm, seldom paired, sparse soft stellate hairs mostly on veins, ovate to elliptic, apex acuminate, base rounded; inflorescence 1-8 mm, axillary between a leaf and a new twig or at the end of a new twig; flowers with pedicels 7-10 mm, calyx with 10 linear appendages, 3 mm long, corolla white, 2 cm across, lobes fused almost to apex, yellow anthers; fruit 1-2 cm, globose, bright red-orange.

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: Forest edge, large gaps and stream margins in forest.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? liana of forest edges and gaps ? white flowers, 2 cm across, corolla lobes fused almost to the tips ? globose red-orange 2 cm fruit

Items.name: Local distribution
Items.Item: Pacific slope at 1200-1600 m; also Atlantic slope at 600-1300 m (San Miguel, Refugio Eladio, Las Nubes).

Items.name: Phenology
Items.Item: Flowers: may-jun, sep-jan. Fruit: apr, jul-oct.

EFGLists.name: Sim Species with desc
EFGLists.EFGList: Lycianthes synanthera#? has smaller blue flowers and yellow fruit
and generally occurs at higher elevation.?

Items.name: Comments
Items.Item: Occurs as high as 850 m in the Peñas Blancas drainage (Eladio, Poco Sol).

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: Hemi-epiphytic shrub with branches to 2 m long; twigs and leaves densely coated with stalked stellate and branched hairs; leaves paired, petioles to 1 cm, blades to 11 x 26 cm, elliptic, asymmetric, acuminate, base acute and unequal, veins expressed above and below, slightly bullate, minor leaf broadly elliptic, 30-50% as long as major leaf; flowers sessile, arising between leaf pairs, pedicel and calyx stellate pubescent, corolla purple-blue, about 1 cm long; fruit a yellow berry.

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: Grows on tree trunks in open forest, forest edge, and pastures in wet forest habitats.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? hemi-epiphyte ? paired leaves with dense stellate hairs ? blue waxy flowers ? yellow berries

Items.name: Local distribution
Items.Item: Atlantic slope from lowlands to 900 m (Río Peñas Blancas valley).

EFGLists.name: Sim Species with desc
EFGLists.EFGList: Lycianthes sanctaeclarae#? a hemi-epiphyte on the lower Atlantic slope below 900 m
with stellate pubescent leaves and larger blue flowers and yellow fruit.?

Items.name: Comments
Items.Item: The attractive flowers produce a very pleasant fragrance. These are often common epiphytes on the trunks of trees in pastures below the level of the cloud forest.

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: Woody hemi-epiphyte with branches to 3 m; leaves paired, glabrous; flowers sessile in leaf axils, few to numerous, calyx cup-like, 4 mm, without lobes, corolla lavender-blue, anthers yellow; fruit to 6 mm long x 10 mm diameter, yellow when mature.

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: Forest canopy and in pasture trees.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? large hemi-epiphyte ? leaves paired, glabrous ? flowers lavender with recurved lobes ? fruit a yellow berry

Items.name: Local distribution
Items.Item: From 800-1500 m on Pacific slope (common at 1400-1500 m); rare on Atlantic slope (1200-1600 m).

EFGLists.name: Sim Species with desc
EFGLists.EFGList: Schultesianthus megalandrus#?- a hemi-epiphyte with smaller leaves not bunched at twig tips and white
flowers do not hang downward on long inflorescence.?

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: A small to large hemi-epiphytic shrub with branches to 2 m long; leaves to 8 x 15 cm, bunched at the twig tips, long petioles, elliptic to obovate, acuminate, base obtuse, entire, fleshy and glabrous; inflorescense with an elongate (to 1 m) dangling peduncle, flowers grouped at apex; flowers green shaded with purple, bell-shaped, 3-4 cm long, large calyx lobes; fruit a 2 cm berry with large persisting calyx lobes.

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: Grows on tree trunks, usually below the crown, often in lighter areas of forest; also in pasture trees.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? epiphyte or hemi-epiphyte ? medium to large fleshy leaves bunched at twig tips ? purple-green flowers at tip of long dangling inflorescence

Items.name: Local distribution
Items.Item: Cloud forest and wet Atlantic slope to lowlands.

Items.name: Phenology
Items.Item: Flower: jan, mar, apr-may, oct. Fruit: .

Items.name: Comments
Items.Item: Rarely seen in flower in the Monteverde area.

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: Slender semi-woody climbers; latex clear or only slightly milky; leaves opposite, to 6 x 10 cm, entire, glabrous, elliptic to oblong, acute with rounded to obtuse base, slightly fleshy; axillary inflorescence bearing several flowers in sequence over many days; flowers about 1.5 cm long with spreading 1 cm ,yellow-green lobes; fruit are slender follicles attached at the base.

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: Light gaps in forest and forest edge.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? slender woody climbers, without stipules, clear latex. ? leaves opposite, elliptic, glabrous, slightly fleshy. ? flower 5-lobed, yellow lobes bent like a pinwheel. ? fruit a pair of long, slender pods connected at base.

Items.name: Local distribution
Items.Item: Premontane wet forest zone on Pacific slope below level of cloud forest at 1350 to 1550 m.

Items.name: Phenology
Items.Item: Flower: apr, jun, jul, nov. Fruit: apr.

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: Stout woody climbers reaching 15 m high; latex clear or slightly milky; leaves opposite, glabrous, oblong-elliptic, thick and fleshy, to 8 x 18 cm; petioles about 2 cm; flowers about 2 cm long with spreading 10-13 mm lobes yellow-green with purplish tips, the central ring yellow; fruit a pair of slender follicles united at base, to 35 cm long.

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: Forest edge, secondary forest, and disturbed areas.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? woody climbers, without stipules, with clear or slightly milky latex.. ? leaves opposite, thick and fleshy, glabrous. ? flower 5-lobed, lobes bent like a pinwheel. ? fruit a pair of long, slender pods connected at base.

Items.name: Local distribution
Items.Item: Lowland wet, moist, and semi-deciduous forest on both slopes up to about 1000 m on the Atlantic slope.

Items.name: Phenology
Items.Item: Flower: apr, jul, oct, dec. Fruit: apr, jun, aug, dec.

Items.name: Species range
Items.Item: Mexico to Colombia (and possibly to Peru).

EFGLists.name: Sim Species with desc
EFGLists.EFGList: Merinthopodium neuranthum#?? a hemi-epiphyte with purplish-green flowers on long dangling inflorescences. Schultesianthus leucanthus and Schultesianthus venosus? rare hemi-epiphytes with longer
narrower white flowers. Bourreria costaricensis? a tree with similarly shaped white flowers the style is forked.?

Items.name: Comments
Items.Item: An attractive plant with showy flowers and a pleasant fragrance. Individual plants vary considerably in corolla length.

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: Hemi-epiphyte, often with stems ascending tree trunks and branches, leaves simple, bunched at twig tips, to 6 x 10 cm long, glabrous, thick, entire, elliptic to obovate, apex blunt acute to rounded, minutely punctate below; flowers on short congested inflorescences near twig tips, calyx 1 cm, corolla 3.5-5 cm long, white when fresh, turning cream yellow by third day, fragrant during day; fruit a 2 cm purple-black globose berry.

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: Primary and disturbed cloud forest, wet forest and rain forest.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? hemi-epiphyte on tree trunks ? leaves thick with blunt to rounded apex ? stout white to cream yellow flowers with 5 lobes ? fruit a purple-black 2cm berry

Items.name: Local distribution
Items.Item: Pacific slope cloud forest and Atlantic slope wet forest down to about 800 m (Río San Gerardo valley, Río Peñas Blancas valley).

Items.name: Phenology
Items.Item: Flower: feb, mar, may-jun. Fruit: jul-sep.

Items.name: Species range
Items.Item: Mexico to Venezuela, Colombia, and Ecuador
