EFGList.serviceLink: Merinthopodium neuranthum#?- a hemi-epiphyte with purple-green flowers on long dangling inflorescences stalks.?

Items.name: Comments
Items.Item: The corollas of fresh flowers are nearly white, but they turn orange with age and become conspicuous when they litter the ground under a large flowering plant. The leaves are generally a lighter green than surrounding foliage. Using a night viewing scope, I have observed hawkmoths visiting the flowers at night, but not bats as some people have suggested. Widely cultivated.

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: A canopy liana, to 6 cm diameter with tan checkered bark; leaves alternate and solitary, with long petioles, fleshy, glabrous, ovate to elliptic; large white to orange tubular flowers, 20 cm long, with purple lines inside corolla and somewhat frilly lobes, 5 large, elongate calyx lobes; fruit to 7 cm, ovate, shaped like a top with persistent style and large calyx lobes.

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: Ascending trees in both forest and forest edge.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? canopy liana ? fleshy leaves bunched at twig tips ? 20 cm tubular flowers ? top-shaped fruit with elongate calyx lobes

Items.name: Local distribution
Items.Item: On the Pacific slope from the upper San Luis Valley to the edge of the cloud forest in the premontane zone at about 900 to 1500 m.

Items.name: Species range
Items.Item: Mexico to Panama. Widely cultivated in the tropics

EFGLists.name: Sim Species with desc
EFGLists.EFGList: more deeply lobed leaves with heavier spines
and the fruit lacks glandular sticky hairs and usually lacks the characteristic orangy pubescence of S. accrescens.?

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: Treelet, 2-5 m, secondary forest and old pasture; spines on stem, twigs, and leaf midvein, rusty pubescent; petiole to 4 cm, blade to 13 x 22 cm, rusty pubescent with stellate hairs, with or without 1-4 tooth-like lobes; inflorescence opposite petiole or internodal; flower with corolla white, 1.5 cm, lobes 13 mm, free nearly to base, stamens yellow, narrowed to tip with small pores, 6 mm, equal; fruit to 15 mm, globose, yellow-green, pubescent with sticky glandular hairs, calyx 16 mm; seed 3-4 mm, kidney-shaped, orange-tan.

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: Overgrown pastures, forest edge, roadside, coffee plantations.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? spiny treelet, 2-5 m ? leaves with small lobes and rusty stellate hairs ? flower white, lobes free nearly to base ? fruit with sticky glandular hairs and large calyx

EFGLists.name: Sim Species with desc
EFGLists.EFGList: small tree found in same habitat

Items.name: Comments
Items.Item: The growth form is usually erect with a single stem. Grows in light gaps, pastures and roadsides in cloud forest; less common lower on the dry Pacific slope.

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: Erect herb, 1-2 m; stems and leaves with dense straight spines; leaves large with prominent tooth-like lobes; flowers 1.5-2.5 cm across, pale green with yellow anthers, calyx spiny; fruit 1-2 cm, globose, green with darker green streaking, surface sticky.

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: Light gaps, road sides, and overgrown pastures.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? large herb with dense long straight spines ? leaves with distinct lobes ? flowers pale green ? fruit sticky, marked with green marbling

Items.name: Local distribution
Items.Item: Cloud forest above 1500 m elevation; less common in Pacific slope wet forest down to 1300 m and down to 900 on the Atlantic side.

Items.name: Phenology
Items.Item: Flower: most of the year (mar, jul, sep-nov). Fruit: becoming mature during flowering (jul).

Items.name: Species range
Items.Item: Mexico to South America (Venezuela, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru)

EFGLists.name: Sim Species with desc
EFGLists.EFGList: ?Several other glabrous and spineless species of Solanum treelets occur in the area
Solanum brenesii# Solanum pastillum# Solanum rovirosanum#Solanum tuerckheimii#?. Of these
Solanum rovirosanum#? with obovate 15-30 cm leaves wetter forest above 1400 m and ?

Items.name: Comments
Items.Item: This tree was identified years ago as S. nudum, which is now considered to be a distinct species restricted to South America. S. aphyodendron is abundant in areas of early succession. The torn leaves produce a strong, acrid odor. As in other species of Solanum, the flowers do not produce nectar and offer pollen as the only reward to visitors, which tends to elliminate almost everything but bees. The bees hold the anthers in their mandibles and vibrate them using their wing muscles to make the pollen issue out of the tiny pores at the anther's tip. Bats remove the fruits so consistently that ripe fruits are seldom seen.

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: Treelet, 2-5 m; leaves often paired, to 4 x 12 cm, glabrous, lanceolate, with a strong rank odor when shredded; flowers 1 cm, white with yellow anthers; fruit to 1.5 cm, globose, green to dull yellow when mature with many flat seeds.

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: Old pasture, roadside and forest edge.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? a 2-5 m treelet, no spines ? paired glabrous leaves less than 5 cm wide ? white flower with yellow anthers ? rank odor

Items.name: Local distribution
Items.Item: Pacific slope at 1200-1600 m; Atlantic slope at 1100-1600 m.

Items.name: Phenology
Items.Item: Flower: feb, apr-oct. Fruit: apr, aug-dec.

EFGLists.name: Sim Species with desc
EFGLists.EFGList: Solanum ramonense#?- another small shrub with swollen nodes and small white flowers

EFGList.caption: Solanum_rovirosanum#?-_with_similar_leaf_comformation
EFGList.serviceLink: but veins glabrous and leaves not crowded.?

EFGLists.EFGList: Solanum rovirosanum#?- with similar leaf comformation

EFGList.caption: is_a_much_larger_plant.?
EFGList.serviceLink: but veins glabrous and leaves not crowded.?

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: A shrub mature at 0.5 m, rarely more than 1 m tall, little branched, nodes swollen; leaves distichous, paired, to 10 x 20 cm long, obovate, acute, the minor leaves much smaller than the majors, petioles and internodes short so that leaves are crowded and cover the stem, glabrous except for erect small hairs on the veins below; flowers with white corolla 6-9 mm across, yellow anthers on short, few-flowered inflorescence opposite the leaves; fruit to 12 mm, globose, yellow-green at maturity.

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: Forest understory, especially in sheltered wet places.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? small shrubs with swollen nodes, crowded leaves, short petioles ? small white flowers on very short inflorescences ? round yellow-green fruit

Items.name: Local distribution
Items.Item: Pacific slope cloud forest and Atlantic slope to the lowlands.

Items.name: Phenology
Items.Item: Flower: mar-apr, jun-jul, dec. Fruit: mar-may.

EFGLists.name: Sim Species with desc
EFGLists.EFGList: Solanum schlechtendalianum#? has leaves with white underside
but the stellate hairs are not scale-like and the leaf is not glossy.?

Items.name: Comments
Items.Item: Not known to be an ithomiine hostplant. Very similar to S. schlechtendalianum, which has an even stronger unpleasant odor.

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: Treelet mature at 2-8 m; twigs slender, covered with whitish, scale-like, stellate hairs; leaves distichous, mostly solitary, but paired where an inflorescence arises, petiole 8-10 mm, blade to 6 x 14 cm, dark green above, glossy white below with dense, appressed scale-like hairs, elliptic to lanceolate, vains keeled above, weakly bullate, minor leaves ovate, 30-50% the length of major leaves, strong acrid odor in shredded leaf; inflorescence arising next to minor leaf, peduncle to 5 cm, bent somewhat underneath major leaf, branched apically; flowers with corolla lobes green-white, 4 mm long, anthers yellow, blunt, 2 mm; fruit globose black berries to 10 mm, pedicels 7-9 mm, apically thickened.

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: Old pastures, forest edge, light gaps and stream margins in forest.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? erect, 2-8 m treelets ? leaves glossy white below from dense scale-like, stellate hairs ? small green-white flowers, 8-10 mm across ? globose black berries on pendant penduncles

Items.name: Local distribution
Items.Item: Pacific slope at 1000- 1500 m; Atlantic slope from lowlands to 1300 m.

EFGLists.name: Herbivores
EFGLists.EFGList: Hyalyris excelsa#Mechanitis lysimnia#Mechanitis menapis#Mechanitis polymnia#Scada zibia#

EFGLists.name: Sim Species with desc
EFGLists.EFGList: Solanum lanceifolium#? occurs at lower elevations on both slopes
much less hairy and the hairs are short-stalked
Solanum chrysotrichum#? has larger lobed leaves
and broad corolla lobes fuzed in the basal half.?

Items.name: Comments
Items.Item: Formerly called Solanum siparunoides. This heavily spined climber is common on forest edges, in open pastures, and on roadsides, but occasionally also grows as a high-climbing liana in the forest, usually in old tree fall gaps. This wide-ranging plant is eaten by more ithomiine species than just about any other member of the Solanaceae in Costa Rica. It becomes increasingly scarce down the dry Pacific slope below Monteverde.

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: Sprawling shrub or liana to 15 m; dense stalked stellate hairs and curved spines on stems and leaves; leaves paired, medium sized with a few poorly defined marginal points; flowers 3--4 cm across, corolla white flushed with lavender or purple, lobes narrow and free almost to base; fruit 2 cm, globose, orange.

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: Light gaps in forest, forest edge, overgrown pastures.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? high-climbing liana or sprawling shrub in pastures ? dense stellate hairs and recurved spines ? paired leaves with small marginal points ? 3 cm flowers, white flushed with lavender

Items.name: Local distribution
Items.Item: Wet forest on Pacific slope from 1300 m to high cloud forest; down to lowlands on Atlantic slope.

Items.name: Phenology
Items.Item: Flower: most of the year (dec-may). Fruit: most of year (jun-jul).

Items.name: Seed dispersers
Items.Item: Birds (and possibly bats and arboreal mammals)

EFGLists.name: Sim Species with desc
EFGLists.EFGList: Solanum rovirosanum#?- leaves larger and obovate.?

Items.name: Comments
Items.Item: This species has been lumped with S. rovirosanum by some taxonomists, but it is clearly distinct in both habitat and morphology in the Monteverde region.

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: Tree, mature at 3-8 m; leaves paired, glabrous, narrowly elliptic, apex acute, base acute, lateral veins 7-9, flat to weakly expressed above, expressed below; inflorescence 1-2 cm, arising next to minor leaf; flower with corolla white, lobes 8-11 mm, free nearly to base, anthers yellow; fruit to 12 x 13 mm, almost globose, calyx appressed, pedicel 12 mm; seeds green, soft and rubbery when mature.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? leaves paired, glabrous, narrowly elliptic ? flower with white corolla, yellow anthers ? fruit round, yellow-green with soft green seeds

EFGLists.name: Sim Species with desc
EFGLists.EFGList: Solanum acerifolium#?- an herb with lobed leaves
but straight spines. The very similar Solanum rudepannum occurs below about 700 m one both slopes and the two species may hybridize.?

Items.name: Comments
Items.Item: Locally common in pastures and overgrown roadsides, rare in cloud forest gaps and landslides. Becomes scarcer down the dry Pacific slope.

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: Shrub or small tree mature at 1.5-6 m; curved spines on stem, branches, petiole and veins; leaves large with shallow lobes, stem leaves with deeper lobes, pubescence of stellate hairs; flowers 3 cm across, white with yellow anthers, corolla partly fused; fruits to 2 cm, globose, dull yellow when mature.

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: Roadsides, abandoned pastures, landslides, disturbed soil.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? woody shrub or small tree ? stout curved spines and shallowly lobed leaves ? 3 cm white flowers

Items.name: Local distribution
Items.Item: Grows on Pacific slope above 1400 m and down to 800 m on Atlantic slope; at the TV towers (1860 m).

Items.name: Phenology
Items.Item: Flower: most of year, especially wet season (dec, jan, mar, may). Fruit: mature during and after flowering (may-jun).

EFGLists.name: Sim Species with desc
EFGLists.EFGList: Solanum umbellatum#? also grows in disturbed areas and has pubescent leaves
but they are much larger and the inflorescences stand erect above the leaves.?

Items.name: Comments
Items.Item: Solanum extensum Bitt. is considered a synonym.

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: Treelet, mature at 2-5 m, without spines; petioles to 5 mm; leaves to 4 x 13 cm, lance-elliptic, with soft stellate hairs, membranous; inflorescence with peduncles 1-2 mm, flower with slender pedicels to 15 mm, corolla white, 7 mm long, stamens yellow; infructescence with peduncle to 3 mm, with up to 8 fruit; fruit to 10 mm, shiny purple-black, globose, pedicel 15 mm; seed 2 x 3 mm, 3-8 seeds/fruit.

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: Old pastures, forest edge, stream margins within forest, and secondary forest.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? slender treelet without spines ? small lance-elliptic leaves with stellate hairs ? small white flowers with yellow anthers ? round black 1 cm fruit

Items.name: Comments
Items.Item: This species can form dense thickets that are difficult to penetrate because of the sharp spines. It barely reaches the 700 m cutoff for our flora study area at Poco Sol.

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: Erect or sprawling shrubs to 3 m tall; armed with short curved spines; leaves paired, subequal, 7-10 cm long, with dense stellate hairs, somewhat rhombic with 2-3 short lateral lobes; flower about 1 cm across, with corolla white, the narrow lobes stellate pubescent externally, yellow anthers; fruit to 1 cm, a globose, red-orange berry.

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: Overgrown pastures, roadsides, and secondary areas.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? shrub of pastures and roadsides with short curved spines. ? leaves paired, pubescent, with short lateral lobes. ? fowers small, white with yellow anthers. ? fruit are small orange berries.

Items.name: Local distribution
Items.Item: Atlantic lowlands up to about 800 m.

Items.name: Species range
Items.Item: Southern U.S. to South America and Antilles.

EFGLists.name: Sim Species with desc
EFGLists.EFGList: but leaves larger with dense stalked stellate hairs

Items.name: Comments
Items.Item: More secondary in habitat preference than S. siparunoides and occupies a drier, more seasonal vegetation zone.

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: Liana, 2 to 7 m; stems armed with short curved spines; leaves paired, fine stellate pubescent, petiole 3-5 cm, often with spines, blade to 5 x 14 cm, ovate to elliptic, apex and base acute to obtuse, entire or with several weak tooth-like lobes, main veins with sparse recurved spines, flower with corolla to 10 mm long, 11-15 mm diameter, white, anthers 5 mm long, yellow; fruit 8-10 mm, globose, red-orange, with many flat seeds.

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: Forest edge, large light gaps, secondary vegetation, overgrown pastures.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? woody climber with paired weakly-lobed leaves ? hook-like spines and fine stellate hairs ? flowers 1 cm, white with yellow anthers ? fruit a 1 cm red-orange berry

Items.name: Species range
Items.Item: Mexico to northern South America and Antilles

EFGLists.name: Sim Species with desc
EFGLists.EFGList: Solanum rudepannum#? are similar spiny shrubs with pure white corollas. Solanum wendlandii is a spiny liana of wetter habitats with deeply lobed
glabrous leaves and large blue flowers

Items.name: Comments
Items.Item: This species was called Solanum hartwegii in the past.

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: Shrub, maturing at 0.5-2 m tall, short stout spines on stem and branches; leaves paired, stem leaves often much larger and deeply lobed, upper leaves averaging 8 x 12 cm, elliptic, not conspicuously lobed, densely coated below with white stellate hairs; inflorescences internodal, usually forked 1-1.5 cm above base; flowers pale blue, 20-25 mm across, anthers yellow to orange, 6-8 mm, tapering, fruit a globose berry to 2 cm, green to dull yellow to orange at maturity.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? leaves with shallow, tooth-like lobes ? dense wooly white stellate hairs on leaf underside ? flowers pale blue with yellow-orange anthers ? globose orange fruit

Items.name: Local distribution
Items.Item: Dry Pacific slope below Monteverde, San Luis valley, along road from Santa Elena to Highway, 800-1000 m. Premontane moist and Premontane wet forest life zones.

Items.name: Phenology
Items.Item: Flower: jan-mar, jun-aug, oct. Fruit: may-jul.

EFGLists.name: Sim Species with desc
EFGLists.EFGList: Solanum tuerckheimii#?- cracked reddish bark and veins not impressed above
grows in drier habitats on the Pacific slope.?

Items.name: Comments
Items.Item: This shade tolerant species is distinctive in its slender zig-zag twigs, slender inflorescences, and knob-like calyx lobes.

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: A shrub or treelet mature at 1-4 m; twigs slender with petiole ridges continuing onto twigs forming narrow keels that border the entire internode; petioles to 1 cm, leaves to 7 x 16 cm, mostly paired, glabrous, weakly bullate, elliptic to ovate, apex acuminate, base acute, minor leaf ovate, 15-20% as long as major leaf; inflorescence arising on internode, but closer to upper node, peduncle slender and pendant; flower with corolla pale green, the lobes with canoe-shaped tips, anthers yellow; fruit to 1.5 cm, globose, becoming yellow-green when mature.

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: Light gaps and partly shaded forest edges, stream margins, and roadsides.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? 1-4 m treelet, shade tolerant ? paired glabrous leaves ? twigs with fine ridges ? inflorescences arising between nodes

Items.name: Local distribution
Items.Item: Cloud forest on both slopes; less commonly in Pacific slope wet forest, especially along streams.

EFGLists.name: Sim Species with desc
EFGLists.EFGList: inflorescence usually longer than pedicel and often branched
Solanum ramonense#?- twig nodes more swollen
with a yellow cast below and glabrous

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: Shrub or treelet mature at 1-2 m; twigs round, rarely with fine ridges, minute erect pubescence, nodes swollen; leaves mostly solitary, distichous, petiole 8-10 mm, blade lanceolate to elliptic, apex acuminate, base acute, margin undulate, texture thin, veins with persistent short erect pubescence below, midvein keeled above, lateral veins 7-10, expressed finely above, strongly below, weakly bullate, odor weak; inflorescence 3-10 mm, unbranched; flower 7-10 mm, white with yellow anthers, pedicel 15-18 mm, very slender at base and widening gradually to apex; fruit gobose, 15 mm, yellow-green when mature; about 20 seeds per fruit, seed 4-5 mm x 3-4 mm x 2 mm, light green with a leathery coat.

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: Open understory of primary forest, understory of secondary forest, bordering forest trails and gaps.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? understory treelet to 2 m tall ? leaves held in a plane, wavy margins, pubescent on veins below ? small white flowers on slender 15-20 mm pedicels ? globose yellow-green fruit on long pedicel and short infructescence

Items.name: Local distribution
Items.Item: Wet forest and lower cloud forest on Pacific slope at 1400-1550 m.

Items.name: Phenology
Items.Item: Flower: feb-mar, jun-nov. Fruit: oct-jan, jul.

Items.name: Comments
Items.Item: Native to Ecuador and Colombia, the people here grow the plants for their fruits, which they use to make a uniquely flavored fruit drink called ?Naranjilla.? The fruit itself is generally not eaten as is. They remove the urticating hairs by rubbing the fruit inside a few sheets of newspaper.

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: An herb or weak shrub to 2 m; stems, branches and leaves armed with short spines; leaves densely pubescent with stellate hairs often giving a purplish caste, leaves usually solitary, petioles to 15 cm, blades reaching 30 x 40 cm, with several short lateral lobes; flowers on very short inflorescences, corolla white, 3-5 cm across, purplish pubescent outside; fruit globose, orange, 4-6 cm.

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: Cultivated, but often escapes to pastures, roadsides, and agricultural landscapes.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? weak shrub to 2 m tall. ? leaves pubescent, to 40 cm long, and spiny. ? lavender-white flowers on short inflorescences. ? tomato-sized orange fruit with dense, urticating hairs.

Items.name: Local distribution
Items.Item: Both slopes, but mainly in cooler, wetter habitats on the Pacific side.

EFGLists.name: Sim Species with desc

EFGList.caption: Solanum_pastillum#?_is_a_sympatric_shrub_with_ridged_twigs
EFGList.serviceLink: Solanum rovirosanum#? is a larger treelet from the same habitat with larger flowers and similar fruit.?

EFGLists.EFGList: Solanum pastillum#? is a sympatric shrub with ridged twigs

EFGList.caption: a_more_bullate_leaf
EFGList.serviceLink: Solanum rovirosanum#? is a larger treelet from the same habitat with larger flowers and similar fruit.?

EFGList.caption: and_more_elongate_inflorescences
EFGList.serviceLink: Solanum rovirosanum#? is a larger treelet from the same habitat with larger flowers and similar fruit.?

EFGLists.EFGList: Solanum tuerckheimii#? is a similar an understory shrub
but with cracked reddish bark and nodes not swollen.?

Items.name: Comments
Items.Item: One of the most shade-tolerant Solanum species, yet reproductive individuals are usually associated with forest gaps or edges. Most common around the information center at the MV Cloud Forest Preserve and the Triangle area.

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: Shrubs mature at 0.5-1.5 m; twigs conspicuously swollen, without ridges; leaves paired, glabrous, minor leaves very small and nearly round; inflorescence arising opposite leaves, 2--5 mm long, stiff; flowers with pedicel 5-7 mm, corolla white, 8-9 mm across, lobes 3.5-4 mm long, anthers yellow, blunt, 1.5 mm; fruit to 15 mm, a globose, yellow-green berry .

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: Forest understory, especially where there is extra light.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? 0.5-1.5 m shrub with swollen nodes ? leaves paired, glabrous ? inflorescence opposite leaves ? small white flowers, 8-9 mm across

Items.name: Local distribution
Items.Item: Pacific slope at 1400-1600 m (leeward cloud forest).

Items.name: Phenology
Items.Item: Flower: jan, may. Fruit: mar, may-jul, nov.

EFGLists.name: Sim Species with desc
EFGLists.EFGList: Solanum arboreum#?- a shrub usually less than 1 m tall with similar leaf arrangement

EFGList.caption: Solanum_brenesii#?-_is_a_treelet_with_similar_leaf_conformation
EFGList.serviceLink: but much smaller flowers and leaves.?

EFGLists.EFGList: Solanum brenesii#?- is a treelet with similar leaf conformation

EFGList.caption: but_the_blades_are_narrow_and_elliptic_and_a_more_yellow-green_color
EFGList.serviceLink: but much smaller flowers and leaves.?

EFGLists.EFGList: but the blades are narrow and elliptic and a more yellow-green color
it grows at lower elevations on the Pacific side in more seasonal habitat than S. rovirosanum.?

Items.name: Comments
Items.Item: Sometimes lumped with the distinctive Solaum brenesii.

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: A treelet to 7 m, without spines; leaves paired, petiole to 4 cm, blade to 12 x 35 cm, glabrous, oblanceolate to elliptic, usually widest beyond the middle, often asymmetric,apex acute, base acute,midveins and lateral veins expressed above, lateral veins 10-14, tertiary veins impressed above; inflorescences short, 1-4 cm, opposite the major leaf; flowers to 15 mm across, corolla white, anthers yellow; fruit subglobose, to 18 mm long, yellow-green, glabrous, seeds bean-shaped, not flat.

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: Light gaps and stream margins in mature forest, secondary forest, forest edge, clearings.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? treelet to 7 m tall without spines ? large paired glabrous leaves ? white flowers on short axillary inflorescences ? dull yellow-green fruit

Items.name: Local distribution
Items.Item: Atlantic slope from lowlands up to 1400m; Pacific slope wet forest from 900 to 1500m.

Items.name: Phenology
Items.Item: Flower: feb-may (most of year). Fruit: feb, apr-dec (most of year).

EFGLists.name: Sim Species with desc
EFGLists.EFGList: Solanum argenteum#? is a treelet with the leaves glossy white below from scale-like hairs. Not scale-like in S. schlechtendalianum.?

Items.name: Abundance
Items.Item: Rare on Pacific slope; uncommon on Atlantic slope.

Items.name: Comments
Items.Item: Not known to be an ithomine hostplant. The very strong leaf odor is both unpleasant and indicative. This species is more typical of disturbed ground outside if forest habitats, while S. argenteum is more often found in gaps and road margins within forest.

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: Shrub ir treelet, mature at 1.5 to 8 m; twigs slender, somewhat zigzagging, coated with dense white stellate hairs; leaves distichous, solitary, but paired where an inflorescence arises, densely covered with white, sessile and stalked stellate hairs below giving the underside a powdery white appearance, petiole to 3 mm, blade to 6 x 12 cm, ovate, acuminate, base unequal, weakly bullate veins keeled above, very strong unpleasant leaf odor; inflorescence arising next to minor leaf and bent underneath the accompanying major leaf, which hides the flowers from above; flowers with pedicel 5-8 mm, corolla 5-7 mm long, white shaded with green at base, lobes 5 mm, pubescent outside, glabrous inside, anthers 2mm, blunt, orange, ovary and base of style stellate pubescent; fruit a globose, purple-black, 1 cm berry.

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: Old pastures, forest edge, especially on recently disturbed soil.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? erect shrub or treelet to 8 m ? leaves white below from dense white stellate hairs ? small white flowers ? inflorescence hidden beneath leaf

Items.name: Local distribution
Items.Item: Pacific slope at 700-1200 m (Los Llanos, San Rafael); Atlantic slope from lowlands to about 700 m (Chachagua, La Tigra).

EFGLists.name: Sim Species with desc
EFGLists.EFGList: 2 cm across. Solanum longiconicum- a semi-prostrate herb of high peaks with pinnate leaves with small interstitial leaflets among the large ones and blue flowers

Items.name: Comments
Items.Item: A quite distinctive member of the forest understory because of its compound leaves with deep purple undersides.

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: Herb, 0.5-1.5 m; usually with a single stem branching well above base; leaves pinnate, glabrous, 3-9 lanceolate leaflets to 12 cm long, often dark velvety green above with purple underside; inflorescneces axillary, 1-2 cm; flowers with pedicels 4-8 mm, calyx 1-2 mm, corolla 4-8 mm, pale green to green-white or yellow-green, anthers yellow-green; fruit about 2 x 3 cm tall, teardrop-shaped, green to green-white.

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: Forest understory and edge, especially in light gaps and along sunny trails and streams within forest.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? herb to 1.5 m, forest gaps and edge ? small green-white flowers with yellow-green anthers ? erect spindle-shaped fruit with bumpy surface

Items.name: Local distribution
Items.Item: Extending from the Atlantic lowlands up to 1700 m and down to 900 m on the Pacific slope, confined to wetter microhabitats on the drier Pacific side.

Items.name: Phenology
Items.Item: Flower: jan-feb, apr-jun (anytime of year). Fruit: during and immediately following flowering (jun).

Items.name: Species range
Items.Item: Guatemala to Colombia, Venezuela, and Peru

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: Shrub, to 2 m; stem bark cracking and pealing in red strips; leaves solitary or paired, glabrous, to 5 x 10 cm, elliptic to obovate, acute, base acute to obtuse; inflorescence arising at node, 1-3 cm, unbranched; flower with calyx lobes triangular, corolla 10 mm across, lobes 5 mm long, pale green, anthers yellow; fruit to 15 mm, globose, yellow-green when mature.

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: Understory and gaps in premontane wet forest.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? 1 to 2 m shrub with slender twigs ? bark reddish and cracking longitudinally ? paired glabrous leaves ? small white fowers with yellow anthers ? yellow-green globose fruit

Items.name: Comments
Items.Item: A common weedy treelet in pastures from 1350-1550 m on the Pacific slope. Easy to recognize when fertile by the erect inflorescences.

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: Shrub or treelet to 5 m; densley pubescent with soft stellate hairs; leaves narrowly elliptic with long petioles, not lobed, mostly not paired; 1 cm white flowers with yellow anthers; flowers and fruits on erect inflorescences held above the foliage; fruit to 1.5 cm, a globose dull yellow berry.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? 1.5-5 m treelet, no spines ? narrow elliptic leaves, no lobes, dense stellate hairs ? 1 cm white flowers on erect inflorescence

Items.name: Local distribution
Items.Item: Pacific slope wet forest at 1300 to 1500 m, not entering cloud forest.

Items.name: Phenology
Items.Item: Flower: most of year (jan-feb, jul-aug, oct). Fruit: soon after flowering.

EFGLists.name: Sim Species with desc
EFGLists.EFGList: Witheringia meiantha#?- leaves shiny green above

Items.name: Comments
Items.Item: This species generally grows higher than W. meiantha and is especially common in places exposed to the mists brought in by northeast trade winds, while meiantha grows more commonly in light areas inside the forest and forest edge where protected from the wind.

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: A shrub or treelet reproductive at 1-2.5 m, stems semi-woody and esily broken; petioles to 5 cm, leaves paired, distichous, glabrous, to 9 x 18 cm, elliptic, minor leaves about 60% as long as major and more ovate, upper side matt green, not shiny; flowers almost sessile between leaf pairs, up to 20 per node, pedicels to 2 cm, calyx 3 mm wide, unlobed, corolla lobes 5-6 mm, dull orange, glabrous except on margin, anthers 2.5 mm, dull orange; fruit a bright red berry to 10 mm long.

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: Road cuts, landslides, large light gaps, and pastures especially on ridges and peaks exposed to the trade winds.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? leaves matte green above, not shiny ? flowers dull orange, small ? bright red 1 cm berries

Items.name: Local distribution
Items.Item: Cloud forest on both slopes, mostly above 1550 m.

Items.name: Phenology
Items.Item: Flower: mar-may, nov. Fruit: apr-may. Flowers and fruit during most of the year.

EFGLists.name: Sim Species with desc
EFGLists.EFGList: Cuatresia riparia#?- a treelet with similar leaf arrangement
but glabrous and the flowers are essentially sessile
C. exiguiflora#?- a similar leaf conformation
but the leaves are generally much broader and glabrous

Items.name: Comments
Items.Item: A locally patchy treelet of open understory, gaps and forest edge in cloud forest; restricted to wetter sites in the premontane zone.

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: Treelet, 3-6 m; twigs round, nodes swollen, fine dorsal ridge arising between petioles; leaves often paired, petioles to 15 mm, blades to 5 x 19 cm, narrowly elliptic, asymmetric, glabrous above, soft erect hairs below on blade and veins, evident to touch, minor leaf to 3 x 11 cm, narrowly elliptic to ovate, spicey bean odor in leaf; inflorescence with peduncle 2-5 cm, erect, arising between leaf pairs, with groups of flowers that open successively; flower with pedicel 6-10 mm, calyx 6-7 mm, forming a tube, lobes 1.5 mm, glabrous, corolla 15 mm long, pale green, each lobe with a supapical tooth outside, style 10 mm, stamens tan, filaments pubescent, ovary glabrous; fruit to 13 x 15 mm, subglobose, green-white immature, blue mature, with pedicel 10-12 mm.

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: Open understory, gaps and forest edge in cloud forest; restricted to wetter sites in premontane zone.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? treelet with paired leaves ? erect hairs on the lower midvein ? long stalked inflorescence

Items.name: Local distribution
Items.Item: Pacific slope at 1400-1600 m in premontane wet forest and leeward cloud forest.

EFGLists.name: Sim Species with desc
EFGLists.EFGList: Witheringia solanacea#?- pubescence of leaves is fine and soft
not stiff and erect as in maculata
flowers also with green spots on the lobes inside. Witheringia macrantha- very similar leaves and habit
but flowers larger and with dark purple inside at base of lobes

Items.name: Comments
Items.Item: Apparently similar plants from the cloud forest have flowers with slightly different color patterns- one with green spotting and little purple inside, the other without spots and with more extensive purple around the base of the lobes inside. The second type may be W. macrantha. I have observed large flies visiting the flowers in a hughly determined and experienced way.

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: Herb, 0.5-1 m, all parts with long erect simple hairs; leaves paired, petioles to 5 cm, blades to 12 x 17 cm, ovate, base rounded to weakly lobed, bullate; flowers on long-lived inflorescence to 5 cm long, arising between leaf pairs, calyx cup-like and hairy, splitting irregularly, corolla to 35 mm across, lobes to 17 mm long, cream-yellow with purple shading and green spotting at base inside, hairy outside, glabrous inside; fruit with pedicels to 4 cm, berry bright red, glabrous, to 15 mm diameter; seeds 1.5 mm, flattened, beige.

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: High light places in cloud forest such as light gaps, trails and road margins.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? herb with large paired leaves, dense simple hairs ? large downward-pointing cream-yellow flowers, green spots inside ? red 12 mm berries

EFGLists.name: Sim Species with desc
EFGLists.EFGList: Witheringia coccoloboides#?? larger leaves with a dull

EFGList.caption: Witheringia_solanacea#??_with_pubescent_leaves
EFGList.serviceLink: grows on higher peaks and ridges exposed to Atlantic trade winds.?

EFGList.caption: more_herbaceous
EFGList.serviceLink: grows on higher peaks and ridges exposed to Atlantic trade winds.?

EFGList.caption: rarely_semi-woody
EFGList.serviceLink: grows on higher peaks and ridges exposed to Atlantic trade winds.?

EFGList.caption: generally_grows_at_lower_elevation_below_1500_m.?
EFGList.serviceLink: grows on higher peaks and ridges exposed to Atlantic trade winds.?

EFGLists.EFGList: generally grows at lower elevation below 1500 m.?

Items.name: Comments
Items.Item: Common and conspicuous along the trails and road in the Triangle area of the Cloud Forest Preserve. Occurs within the forest in light gaps and open understory.

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: Semi-woody shrub, mature at 1-2 m; twigs somewhat zig-zag and swollen at the nodes; leaves paired, distichous, glabrous, petioles to 4 cm, blades to 6 x 12 cm, minor leaves 50-70% as long, ovate-elliptic, base often unequal, veins weakly impressed above, membranous, very shiny above; flowers nearly sessile on very short peduncles arising between leaf pairs, with 4-15 flowers, pedicel to 18 mm, calyx 2.7 mm wide, without lobes, corolla 6 mm long with 5 recurved yellow 4 mm lobes, dull yellow, often with purple shading inside, usually without green spots, glabrous; fruit a bright red juicy berry, globose or slightly squashed, to10 mm long.

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: Forest edge, light gaps, stream margins in forest.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? paired glabrous leaves with impressed veins ? small yellow flowers with recurved lobes ? small round red berries

Items.name: Local distribution
Items.Item: Pacific slope from 1300 to 1600 m, uncommon in wet spots lower down; Atlantic slope above about 900 m.

Items.name: Phenology
Items.Item: Most of year, especially wet season.

EFGLists.name: Sim Species with desc
EFGLists.EFGList: Witheringia coccoloboides#?- a common shrub of higher cloud forest and wet Atlantic slope
Witheringia meiantha#?- a common shrub of forest sites with glabrous leaves and similar flowers and fruits.?

Items.name: Comments
Items.Item: The leaves often have pale gray patches, apparently from a disease. Often at the edge of forest/pasture in intermittent shade.

Items.name: Credits
Items.Item: Images and text copyright © 2002-2005 by William A. Haber, www.cs.umb.edu/efg.

Items.name: Description
Items.Item: A weak shrub, reproductive at 0.5 m, rarely reaching 5 m; leaves paired, soft pubescent with simple hairs, dull green above; flowers yellow-green with darker green spots in basal half; fruit 7-12 mm, a bright red, juicy berry.

Items.name: Habitat
Items.Item: Pasture, over grown roadside, forest edge, stream margins, rarely inside mature forest.

Items.name: Identification
Items.Item: ? herb in pastures ? leaves paired with dense soft hairs ? flowers pale yellow with green spots at base ? fruit bright orange, round, 6-10 mm

Items.name: Phenology
Items.Item: Flower: apr-jun. Fruit: apr-may. Flowers and fruits present most of year, but more abundant in wet season.
